channel.title: tastytrade: Market Measures
channel.description: It's not always easy to take the measure of a market, whether you've been trading for a day or a decade. On this segment we look under the hood—options probabilities, volatility, trading strategies, futures, you name it—so your trading mechanics are built to manage more winners.

item.title: Movements of the S&P Components
item.description:
Over the past two years, the majority of the S&P 500 components have been up 55% of the time. In the same time frame, the S&P itself has been up 58% of the time.

Each component is subject to its own implied volatility, but do different levels of the VIX mean different percentages of components being up or down on that day?

item.title: The Tradeoff of Shorter DTE
item.description:
Through our research, we have shown time and time again that selling premium at 45 DTE provides a well-rounded risk-return...but what happens when we trade lower DTE?

Key Takeaways:

  • Shorter DTE trades should have different entry criteria if you choose to trade them...similar to earnings trades, stay extra small and define risk to sustain the increased trade volatility.
  • There are no observable long-term P/L or win rate advantages to trading a certain DTE, but generally lower DTE trades have tight management windows and require frequent attention.

item.title: Where is the Risk with Nat Gas?
item.description:
Natural gas has remained range bound between 2009 and 2021, but in the last month, broke out to above $6. While it is pulling back now, this acts as an indication to where the risk is when trading natural gas.

With equities, the risk lies to the downside as investors and traders worry about their assets going to zero. With natural gas, the risk lies to the upside because the demand increases much faster than the supply can keep up.

How do calls and puts in UNG compare to calls and puts in SPY, and where does the real risk lie?

item.title: Why Ever Sell Calls?
item.description:
Considering that calls are cheaper to begin with than puts, why would we ever sell calls?

Although calls are cheaper and more susceptible to positive market drift over time, the worst case outlier is far less dangerous than the put side (for SPY). Even in the above-average bull market since 2005, selling 16∆ calls in SPY basically broke even, and the POP was still very high.

item.title: What Happens When a Strangle Gets Tested?
item.description:
As we’ve discussed in previous studies, the probability of touch for a single option is roughly equal to 2 * the delta of the option.

The probability of touch does not necessarily mean that the option will expire in the money, however, the probability of expiring in the money does increase.

Following an option getting tested, what happens next? Does the underlying continue in that direction or does it reverse back?

item.title: Intraday Liquidity
item.description:
Even though the morning session has the most volume and arguably the highest per minute volatility, a single trader’s order size is a drop in the bucket for most liquid underlyings’ volume. 

Unless you are attempting to fill an order at open or at close, the time of day is irrelevant when it comes to placing a trade.

item.title: How to Diversify Using Crypto
item.description:
Traders and investors alike want to get exposure to the crypto market, but are unsure how to go about that. 

Crypto is seen as a very volatile asset, so it is difficult to imagine how you could add crypto to your portfolio without increasing portfolio volatility.

The key with adding crypto to your portfolio is making sure to size your position appropriately.

Tom and Tony look at how tastytraders can add crypto to their portfolio without increasing their overall daily portfolio volatility.

item.title: Is BPR Still the Worst Case Estimator?
item.description:
In 2019, tastytrade studied the effectiveness of a short strangle’s buying power reduction as an estimator for worst case loss.

    The reason for this conclusion is that before 2020, there was never a loss on a 16∆ strangle in SPY that exceeded the initial BPR, including 2008.

    Did the move in 2020 change this conclusion?

    In 2020, we saw three occurrences where the loss on a 16∆ SPY strangle exceeded the initial BPR. Note that individual stocks can experience different outcomes. In higher IV environments, the worst loss as % of BPR including 2020 was 75%. Going forward, the BPR still remains an estimator of the worst case scenario on an undefined risk trade.

item.title: ROC in High vs Low IVR
item.description:
We’ve looked at how various IV environments impact the risk associated with strangles, but how does it impact your return on capital (ROC)?

As IVR increases, so does the initial credit we collect on our trades, but is this correlated with the ROC?

Let’s take a look at SPY strangles since 2005 to see if this is the case!

item.title: Markets Are Not Equal to Casinos
item.description:
Opening a brokerage account for the sole purpose of gambling is like going to a great seafood place and ordering a steak...you can get a better steak for the same price at a steakhouse.

In 2020, maybe some people started looking into the markets because of the allure of big movers...but they would not stick around if they genuinely had no interest in learning about investing or managing their own money.

item.title: Tail Risk with Strangles
item.description:
Join Tom and Tony as they look at the tail risk that comes with trading strangles on SPY and when these events are most likely to occur.

16 delta strangles on SPY have an extremely high win rate, at roughly 80%, but they are still exposed to sizable tail risk.

How likely is it to see losers of varying magnitude, and just how bad can these losers be? Tune in to find out!

item.title: The Risk of Getting Big
item.description:
When trading options, it is crucial to understand the risk you carry when selling premium...over-allocating an options portfolio is a non-issue 80 to 90% of the time but a critical issue during market panics. 

The goal of a successful options trader is to “stay in business”. The variable that will most affect this is the portfolio exposure in the dull markets leading up to a crash.

item.title: What Does It Take to Crush Volatility?
item.description:
Even though implied volatility may be inversely correlated to the direction of the market, the underlying reason that causes IV to change is actual moves vs expected moves, and the fear of future actual moves being larger than currently priced.

This played out perfectly in the 2020 selloff...where the VIX continued to expand as the down days got worse, but as soon as we saw a 2% down day when a 4% move was expected, VIX immediately collapsed.

item.title: How Does a Daily 2% Move Impact the VIX?
item.description: tastytrade looks at how the same size moves in the SPX can impact VIX in different ways, depending on where VIX started.This week we have seen higher levels of volatility market-wide, with SPY, QQQ, and IWM hitting their highest IV levels since May. We analyzed 2% or greater down moves in the SPX from 1990 to present to see why we saw such a large increase, on a percent basis, in the VIX this week.VIX moves most aggressively at low levels, which is why we often say don’t sell in low IV environments.

item.title: Large Consecutive Down Days
item.description:
Streaks of large down days are quite uncommon, with only 31 streaks of 3 or more 1% down moves in the SPX since 1993, looking at ~8000 trading days of data. 

The biggest move in a streak tends to be the third day, with an average SPX move of nearly -3% coupled with an expansion of 3 points in the VIX.

item.title: Do Win Rates of Sectors Differ?
item.description:
The theoretical win rate for a 16 delta strangle should be just over 68%, but our previous studies have shown that the win rate comes in higher than that. Do the major sectors follow this trend?

tastytrade looks at the 3 largest companies in the energy, technology, financials, healthcare, and utilities sector ETFs to see how their win rates compare.

Join Tony and TP as they discuss win rates across sectors and what the relationship is between win rate, IV, and premium.
